title: Quebec cuts level of lead allowed in drinking water | CBC News
text:
The Quebec government has announced it will fall in line with federal guidelines on lead levels in drinking water.

In March, Health Canada cut the acceptable concentration of the metal from 10 micrograms per litre to five micrograms per litre. Quebec will follow suit, said Lionel Carmant, the province's junior health minister.

"The government wants to attain the level set out by Health Canada, and what's more, work toward the safest level possible — no lead," he said.

The government originally intended to change the provincial standard by spring 2020, but Environment Minister Benoit Charette said it will be done sooner, making Quebec the first province to do so.

Carmant, Charette, Municipal Affairs Minister Andrée Laforest and Horacio Arruda, Quebec's director of public health, all spoke at a news conference in Quebec City Wednesday and stressed the province's drinking water supply is good quality.

Horacio Arruda, Quebec's director of public health, Lionel Carmant, junior health minister, Environment Minister Benoit Charette and Municipal Affairs Minister Andrée Laforest all stressed there's nothing wrong with Quebec's drinking water. (Sylvain Roy Roussel/CBC)

The issue is with the pipes — lead is usually found in drinking water after leaching from a home or building's plumbing system. Exposure to the metal can have effects on neurological development and behaviour in children, and lead to increased blood pressure or kidney problems in adults.

The government wants municipalities across Quebec to come up with plans to reduce the levels of lead in the water supply. Those plans must include:

Determining the neighbourhoods with homes that are most likely to have a lead service pipe, and a timetable for identifying those sectors.

Figuring out how long it will take to replace all lead service entrances.

Evaluating how much the process will cost.

Coming up with a way to prioritize the work.

The testing method, which currently involves running water for five minutes before sampling, will also be changed, Carmant said.

Now, water samples will be collected right when the tap is turned on, and again after a stagnation period of 30 minutes.

The Education Ministry will use the same standards to evaluate drinking water in schools, Carmant said. Earlier this month, Education Minister Jean-François Roberge ordered every public and private school in the province to test the drinking water for lead.

This summer, Quebec's public health research institute (INSPQ) made public a study that found 16 per cent of schools in Montreal have at least one faucet or water fountain contaminated by lead, findings that were corroborated.
description: In March, Health Canada cut the acceptable concentration of lead in drinking water from 10 micrograms per litre to five micrograms per litre. Quebec now says it intends to change its standard.
